security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation skill containing markdown with Python/pandas code examples for Excel analysis. No executable code, scripts, network calls, or filesystem access capabilities are implemented. The static findings are false positives from a malfunctioning scanner that incorrectly flagged markdown code fences as shell commands and normal text as cryptographic algorithms.

content.value_statement: Manual Excel analysis takes hours of repetitive work. This skill provides ready-to-use pandas patterns for reading, analyzing, and visualizing spreadsheet data in seconds.
actual_capabilities: Read Excel files with pandas read_excel
Process multiple sheets in a workbook
Generate charts and visualizations with matplotlib
Merge and join multiple Excel files
limitations: Does not modify existing Excel files in place
Cannot parse password-protected or encrypted files

use_cases.title: Automated Reporting
use_cases.description: Automate weekly reports by reading Excel data, generating summaries, and creating charts automatically.

use_cases.title: Spreadsheet Cleanup
use_cases.description: Clean messy spreadsheets by removing duplicates, handling missing values, and standardizing data formats.

use_cases.title: Excel Integration
use_cases.description: Integrate Excel data into Python pipelines by learning proper pandas patterns for data extraction.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Reading
prompt_templates.prompt: Read the Excel file data.xlsx using pandas and show me the first rows and basic statistics.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-Sheet
prompt_templates.prompt: Process all sheets from workbook.xlsx and display summary statistics for each sheet.

prompt_templates.title: Pivot Analysis

prompt_templates.title: Visualization

output_examples.input: Create a pivot table showing sales by region

output: Standardized date formats across all entries

best_practices: Specify sheet_name when reading multi-sheet workbooks to avoid unexpected behavior
Use usecols parameter to read only needed columns for better performance
Convert date columns with pd.to_datetime for proper time-series analysis
anti_patterns: Loading entire large Excel files when only a subset of columns is needed
Not specifying data types, causing pandas to infer types slowly
Modifying the original Excel file instead of saving to a new output file

faq.question: What Python packages are available?
faq.answer: Pandas, openpyxl, xlrd, xlsxwriter, and matplotlib are installed and ready to use.

faq.question: Can this skill read .xls files?
faq.answer: Yes, xlrd is available for reading older .xls format files in addition to modern .xlsx.

faq.question: How do I handle large Excel files?
faq.answer: Use the chunksize parameter or read only specific columns with usecols for better performance.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: This is a documentation skill that shows patterns. Your data is only accessed when you run the code with your files.

faq.question: Can I write formatted Excel files?
faq.answer: Yes, use pandas with openpyxl or xlsxwriter engines for advanced formatting and styling.

faq.question: How does this differ from manual Excel?
faq.answer: Automates repetitive tasks, handles larger datasets, creates reproducible analysis pipelines, and integrates with other Python tools.
